Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Systematic Search for Sub-Parsec Binary Supermassive Black Holes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative project is to carry out a systematic search for sub-parsec supermassive black hole binaries (SBHBs) using as the primary signature the Doppler shift of the broad emission lines emitted by gas that is bound to one of the black holes. Finding such close SBHBs constitutes a crucial test of modern scenarios for galaxy evolution that predict their presence. The program will also test a variety of other physical models that invoke SBHBs to explain the formation of stellar cusps after galaxy mergers and mass deficits therein and models for precessing radio jets and X-shaped radio sources.

Broader impacts of the work include training of an undergraduate student and a postdoc, outreach via public lectures, and lab experiments for non-scientist astronomy students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this program we studied 88 quasars that could host binary super-massive black holes, with masses a million to a billion times that of the Sun. These binary black holes could have formed after the merger of two parent galaxies each with its own black hole. Since galaxy mergers are known the be common and most massive galaxies have black holes at their centers, it is reasonable to expect that binary black holes should abound. But finding them has been a challenge. The discovery of binary black hole would be extremely useful in answering a variety of questions, such as how quickly do black holes sink to the center of the final galaxy after a merger, what processes determine their final state, and how these processes influence the host galaxy. 


The goal of the program was to examine the radial velocity technique used to find candidate binary black holes and evaluate whether the candidates found in this way are indeed binary black holes. The technique is analogous to the method used to find extrasolar planets. Exploiting the Doppler effect we track the velocity of the gas that is carried (or "dragged along") by the black holes as they orbit each other and we test whether the velocity changes with time in a manner consistent with orbital motion. Thus we started with 88 quasars in which the black hole appeared to have a substantial velocity relative to the host galaxy and observed each one of them several more times to measure changes in the velocity. We found that, in one third of the candidates the velocity variations are indeed consistent with orbital motion. However, the orbital periods are likely to be long, perhaps many decades long. Therefore, it is important to continue observations of these promising candidates for many years to come in order to evaluate their credentials further.


In addition to the observationsl campaign, we also tried to test this physical scenario by playing "devil's advocate." We made models for the gas surrounding the black holes and moving with them in their orbits and we investigated whether the method we are using to identify the candidates in the first place can yield misleading results. Using two different families of models (one for binary black holes and one for single black holes) we found that, the velocity measurements we make are a good indicator of binary black holes most of the time but not all the time. In other words, we found that the gas surrounding a single black hole can sometimes appear to be moving as if it is in a binary, when it actually is not.

As part of this program, we trained three undergraduate students, one graduate student, and a post-doctoral scholar in a variety of ways. The undergraduate students have learned the basics of data analysis and scientific computing. The graduate student learned about radiative transfer, fluid mechanics, and general relativity. The post-doctoral scholar was trained in all aspects of the science in this project and also gained a great deal of experience in managing a project of this scale, supervising research students, and presenting the results to the scientific community and the general public. Moreover, we developed a laboratory exercise for an introductory astronomy course in which the students learn about spectroscopy (the main technique used in our research program) and about uncertainties in experimental measurements. An appreciation of the uncertainties in experimental measurements in an inseparable part of the science and a valuable lesson for students to learn.
